pullRequest.body:
Define the null submodule in an `InnerProductSpace` and the null subgroup in a `NormedAddCommGroup` and prove basic properties.

~~Define the null space in an `InnerProductSpace` without `definite` and add `InnerProduceSpace` structure to the quotient by the null space.~~ 

Motivation: This PR has evolved from a PR defining the `SeparationQuotient` for `InnerProductSpace`. That has been done in #17452 and now contains some other things.

---

* [x] Depends on: #17007
* [x] Depends on: #17416 
* [x] Depends on: #17452

@j-loreaux If I use `SeparationQuotient` and take the instance [SeparationQuotient.instAddCommGroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/SeparationQuotient.html#SeparationQuotient.instAddCommGroup), it is different from [AddSubgroup.seminormedAddCommGroupQuotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Quotient.html#AddSubgroup.seminormedAddCommGroupQuotient), correct? Do I have to define the norm again for `SeparationQuotient`?
Yes, it is certainly different, and you'll need to define the norm again, assuming the instance doesn't already exist. But I think this is the cleaner approach.
OK I will try. So I should prove all in [Quotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Quotient.html) again for `SeparationQuotient`, correct?
yes, I would.

You should be able to shortcut a little by: 
* Showing the `Inseparable` relation is an `AddCon`:
```lean
/-- `inseparableSetoid` is an additive congruence relation. -/
def inseparableAddCon [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] : AddCon E where
  __ := inseparableSetoid E
  add' {x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂} (hx : Inseparable _ _) (hy : Inseparable _ _) := show Inseparable _ _ by
    simp_rw [Metric.inseparable_iff_nndist, ← nonpos_iff_eq_zero] at hx hy ⊢
    exact (nndist_add_add_le _ _ _ _).trans <| add_nonpos hx hy
```
* Showing this congruence is the same as the one from your `nullSpace` submodule 
* Fiddling around with defeq to copy things over
Ok, I will try to simply following your comments.
I removed `.carrier` as suggested. In some places I had to use `have : x ∈ nullSpace ↔ x ∈ (@nullSpace M _ : Set M) := by rfl`. I wonder if there is a better way

> I removed `.carrier` as suggested. In some places I had to use `have : x ∈ nullSpace ↔ x ∈ (@nullSpace M _ : Set M) := by rfl`. I wonder if there is a better way

This theorem is called `SetLike.mem_coe`
thank you, I replaced all the immediate `have` with `SetLike.mem_coe`.
sorry, I wanted to change docstrings and theorem/instance names later. I know that the PR is still very much incomplete

I noticed that I need to define the lift of a linear map vanishing on the null space as a linear map. Where should I define it and how? In `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.SeparationQuotient` as a `CLM` or `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.SeparationQuotient`?
ah! what should I do with this PR then?

Probably the thing to do is go through the auxiliary lemmas you wrote and make PRs for the useful ones. Certainly we want the null space as a submodule, and the lift operations on separationQuotient look reasonable to have.
@yoh-tanimoto I have no idea what the status of this PR is. Should it be awaiting review? Are you going to split it into other pieces?

@j-loreaux I am not sure which lifts should be defined and how. I know that there is `lift` as a map, but I guess we would like to have it as a `CLM` `NormedAddMonoidHom` etc. I asked about it here [CLM as NormedAddGroupHom?](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/CLM.20as.20NormedAddGroupHom.3F) but I didn't get a clear answer, so that's why I added `RFC` tag.

The part of this PR concerning `nullSubmodule` could be separately merged, I guess.

> @j-loreaux I am not sure which lifts should be defined and how. I know that there is `lift` as a map, but I guess we would like to have it as a `CLM` `NormedAddMonoidHom` etc. I asked about it here [CLM as NormedAddGroupHom?](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/CLM.20as.20NormedAddGroupHom.3F) but I didn't get a clear answer, so that's why I added `RFC` tag.
> 
> The part of this PR concerning `nullSubmodule` could be separately merged, I guess.

The answer to which lifts should be defined is probably: which ones do you need?

If you can split this PR into pieces, you definitely should. 318 lines is on the longish side. Sometimes its unavoidable, but in this case I think you should split.

OK I will split the PR later.

For my interest, I would like to define GNS representation of C^*-algebras, so `liftCLM` I defined in this PR should be enough. Yet I also defined `liftNormedAddGroupHom` because it seemed independent from `CLM`. Maybe split them as well?

I think at least having:
* A PR about null spaces
* A PR with the lifts

would be a good start.
I left only the stuff concerning the null subspaces. The rest is moved to #18178
@j-loreaux thanks for the review! well, as for why we would like to have `nullSubspace` probably @eric-wieser has something to say?

to be honest, it's not that I have a strong argument for including `nullSubmodule` etc. It is rather a by-product of the initial implementation of the quotient by the null space. We switched to `SeparationQuotient`, but as it was suggested that we wanted the null space as a submodule, I kept it. Currently it is used in #18178, but it will not be difficult to eliminate it.

that said, probably there will be some use of `nullSubmodule` etc. when one formalises representations of the Virasoro algebra or Kac-Moody algebra. There, one would like to know some specific and/or expressions properties of the null vectors, and they are not just something to be quotiented.

another thing that came to my mind is a generalisation to indefinite metric spaces, where the null subspace plays important roles, but maybe that should be structured differently from the current `NormedGroup` etc.

@j-loreaux Does the above motivation convince you? I think that is of practical use in the case of the Virasoro algebra or similar, because one would want to prove that the grading of the original space is inherited to the `SeparationQuotient`.
That's fine. I don't think it's unreasonable to have `nullSubmodule`, I just wanted to make sure there was some other reason than "because we can".

Note that I think you missed moving `isClosed_submodule`. I unresolved the conversation.

Thanks for your work on this! Please fix the above issue, merge master,  and wait for CI before merging.

bors d+

:v: yoh-tanimoto can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
I'm fine with all of this, but I am not sensitive enough to the right design parameters so defer to @eric-wieser and @j-loreaux on all the points.

I suspect that this is not the way to proceed here. Instead, I recommend using [SeparationQuotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Defs/Filter.html#SeparationQuotient).

If we don't already have it, you could show that if `X` is a `Seminormed*` then `SeparationQuotient X` is a `Normed*`. Then you could define the inner product space isntance on `SeparationQuotient X`.

The problem with putting this `InnerProductSpace` instance on `E / nullSpace \bbk E` is that we could end up with non-defeq instances later down the line. Moreover, `SeparationQuotient` does almost exactly what you want already, it just doesn't have the necessary instances yet.

Here's a much shorter way to get the `InnerProductSpace` instance on `SeparationQuotient`:
```lean
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Basic

variable {𝕜 E} [RCLike 𝕜] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] [InnerProductSpace 𝕜 E]

namespace SeparationQuotient

instance : Inner 𝕜 (SeparationQuotient E) where
  inner := SeparationQuotient.lift₂ Inner.inner fun _ _ _ _ hab hcd =>
    ((hab.prod hcd).map continuous_inner).eq

theorem inner_mk_mk (x y : E) :
  inner (mk x) (mk y) = (inner x y : 𝕜) := rfl

instance : InnerProductSpace 𝕜 (SeparationQuotient E) where
  norm_sq_eq_inner := Quotient.ind norm_sq_eq_inner
  conj_symm := Quotient.ind₂ inner_conj_symm
  add_left := Quotient.ind fun x => Quotient.ind₂ <| inner_add_left x
  smul_left := Quotient.ind₂ inner_smul_left

end SeparationQuotient
```

The only thing I suggest here that may require action is to include a few more docstrings on some of the lift lemmas you proved, but on this (and everything else) I defer to more experienced reviewers.

(Thanks, Yoh, for trying to building infrastructure that can be used for GNS!!!)
I'm fine with all of this, but I am not sensitive enough to the right design parameters so defer to @eric-wieser and @j-loreaux on all the points.

I've left a relatively thorough review. BUT, before you undertake the changes, please try to address the following question:

Why do we actually need `nullSubgroup` and `nullSubmodule`? Is there something missing about the `SeparationQuotient` API?

I'm not *necessarily* advocating for closing this PR (at the very least, it adds some lemmas that are missing), but I think this question needs to be addressed, as I'm not yet convinced these new definitions buy us much.

```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma mem_nullSpace_iff {x : E} : x ∈ nullSpace 𝕜 E ↔ ‖x‖ = 0 := Iff.rfl
```

maybe:
```suggestion
lemma inner_eq_zero_of_left_mem_nullSpace (x y : E) (h : x ∈ nullSpace 𝕜 E) : ⟪x, y⟫_𝕜 = 0 := by
```
Either way, please add the spaces around the colon throughout

nit:
```suggestion
lemma nullSpace_le_ker_toDualMap (x : E) : nullSpace 𝕜 E ≤ ker (toDualMap 𝕜 E x) := by
```
(and a few other places)

style nit:
```suggestion
  smul_left x y r := by
```
(and elsewhere)
Is this the only lemma that holds more generally for seminormed inner product spaces? I think a standalone PR that applies this generalization further would be a nice change, and could go in first.

Thank you very much for your comments!
Right, when I introduced `PreInnerProduceSpace.Core`, I just changed `NormedAddCommGroup` to `SeminormedAddCommGroup` when the proof remained valid. Maybe I will look for more results that can hold with Semi with modified proofs.
@eric-wieser I made #17007.

The docs for `Core` say
> Warning: Do not use this [Core](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Basic.html#PreInnerProductSpace.Core) structure if the space you are interested in already has a norm instance defined on it, otherwise this will create a second non-defeq norm instance!

Do we need to worry about that here? Do quotients already inherit a norm / topology from elsewhere?

oh sorry, I had missed it. Surely any quotient of a `SeminormedAddCommGroup` is equipped with the quotient norm. I switched to `InnerProductSpace` and proved also `instance : IsClosed (nullSpace 𝕜 E : Set E)`, so that the quotient is also an instance of `NormedAddCommGroup`.

This isn't true, cauchy-schwarz is not used in this definition at all!

Note you can define this more generally as
```lean
variable {𝕜 E} [SeminormedRing 𝕜] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] [Module 𝕜 E] [BoundedSMul 𝕜 E]

/-- The null space with respect to the norm. -/
def nullSpace : Submodule 𝕜 E where
  carrier := {x : E | ‖x‖ = 0}
  add_mem' {x y} (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) (hy : ‖y‖ = 0) := by
    apply le_antisymm _ (norm_nonneg _)
    refine (norm_add_le x y).trans_eq ?_
    rw [hx, hy, add_zero]
  zero_mem' := norm_zero
  smul_mem' c x (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) := by
    apply le_antisymm _ (norm_nonneg _)
    refine (norm_smul_le _ _).trans_eq ?_
    rw [hx, mul_zero]
```

I see, I will move the docstring to the beginning.

I get "failed to synthesize `BoundedSMul 𝕜 E`", although it is there... why?
```lean4
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Dual
import Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.Quotient

variable (𝕜 E : Type*) [k: RCLike 𝕜]

variable {𝕜 E} [SeminormedRing 𝕜] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] [Module 𝕜 E] [BoundedSMul 𝕜 E]

/-- The null space with respect to the norm. -/
def nullSpace : Submodule 𝕜 E where
  carrier := {x : E | ‖x‖ = 0}
  add_mem' {x y} (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) (hy : ‖y‖ = 0) := by
    apply le_antisymm _ (norm_nonneg _)
    refine (norm_add_le x y).trans_eq ?_
    rw [hx, hy, add_zero]
  zero_mem' := norm_zero
  smul_mem' c x (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) := by
    apply le_antisymm _ (norm_nonneg _)
    refine (norm_smul_le _ _).trans_eq ?_
    rw [hx, mul_zero]
```
You should remove `[k: RCLike 𝕜]`, it conflicts with `[SeminormedRing 𝕜] `

Ah ok, thank you!

I think I will have to wait until I will have decided to use `SeparationQuotient` or the null space by hand.

```suggestion
lemma isClosed_nullSpace : IsClosed (@nullSpace M _ : Set M) := by
```
and throughout

```suggestion
instance : Nonempty (@nullSpace M) := ⟨0⟩
```
which should get the appropriate coercion automatically.

```suggestion
    ‖mk m‖ = 0 ↔ m ∈ nullSpace := by
```
I think you should be taking this as the definition of the norm using `Quotient.lift`, and proving the other results about it.
I think the current definition is parallel to the usual quotient norm (by the null space). Why should I take this as the definition in this case?

I think a strong argument for doing so is to match the convention used to define `dist` here:

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3ca1060d7e48260d1b1b7a0733f887e455455226/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Basic.lean#L191-L193

I see, why is it that way, because you get some equations by definition?

I'm not sure how to keep it consistent between normed group and topological group for something else. For `InnerProductSpace`, I have to define a lift of `toDualMap`. Should I use the lift as just a linear map, continuous linear map or linear isometry? If linear isometry, should it be an extension of a continuous linear map?
I've created #17452 with a version along the lines of what I was thinking. I think there's still a lot of good stuff in this PR, but it probably helps to build up the foundations a little more first.
OK, I will wait until it will be merged. I guess I should lift `toDualMap` as a linear isometry?

```suggestion
/-- `SeparationQuotient.mk` as a `MonoidHom`. -/
@[to_additive (attr := simps) "`SeparationQuotient.mk` as an `AddMonoidHom`."]
```
since there is no such thing as what you wrote in mathlib

```suggestion
noncomputable def liftMonoidHom [CommGroup G] [TopologicalGroup G] [CommGroup H]
```

I think cleaner as
```suggestion
    induction x with | _ x => ?_
    induction y with | _ y => ?_
    simp only
```
(untested)
It gave an error "tactic 'induction' failed, major premise type is not an inductive type Quot Setoid.r". I reverted it for the moment.
While the rest of this PR evolves, would you mind splitting the changes in _this_ file to their own PR, so that we can get them merged quickly?
no problem, done. #17416

This should be stated as
```suggestion
lemma inner_eq_zero_of_left (x y : E) (h : ‖x‖ = 0) :
```
or similar, and can hopefully go in `InnerProducSpace/Basic`.

The existence of `mem_nullSubmodule_iff` as a `@[simp]` lemma means that you should avoid ever writing `∈ nullSubmodule` after that point.

I think this is true more generally:
```lean
lemma norm_sub_eq_norm (x y : E) (h : ‖y‖ = 0) : ‖x - y‖ = ‖x‖ := by
  apply le_antisymm ?_ ?_
  · simpa [h] using norm_sub_le x y
  · simpa [h] using norm_add_le (x - y) y
```
no `InnerProductSpace` needed!
thanks, changed

A much shorter proof is
```lean
  have : nullSubgroup (M := M) = closedBall (0 : M) 0 := by
    ext
    rw [mem_closedBall_zero_iff]
    sorry
  rw [this]
  exact isClosed_ball
```
you might find it easier to define the null subgroup as the place where `‖x‖ ≤ 0`, as then the `sorry` is `rfl` you can drop all the `le_antisymm`s in the other proofs.

A *much* shorter proof is:
```
  isClosed_singleton.preimage continuous_norm
```
changed!

This works without either of the `simp only` lines, I think:
```suggest
/-- The kernel of `normedMk` is `nullSubgroup`. -/
theorem ker_normedMk : (@normedMk M _).ker = nullSubgroup := by
  ext _; exact mk_eq_zero_iff _
```

(I.e. it seems that the extensionality lemma allows the use of `mk_eq_zero_iff` pretty much directly.)

thanks for your review! yes, I would like to have GNS in mathlib.

changed.

Not sure whether this is more clear or user-friendly, but it's interesting just how much Lean can infer in the proof below:

```
lemma eq_of_inseparable (f : NormedAddGroupHom M N) (hf : ∀ x ∈ nullSubgroup, f x = 0) :
    ∀ x y, Inseparable x y → f x = f y :=
  fun _ _ h ↦ eq_of_sub_eq_zero <| by
    rw [← map_sub]
    exact hf _ <| inseparable_iff_norm_zero .. |>.mp h

```
changed.
Maybe docstrings on these, to help when people try to search for them via moogle, as moogle reads docstrings. (I might be wrong about this, though, so I defer to more experienced reviewers!)
docstring added, but I'm not sure if the current `def`s are the right ones. that's why I added `RFC` tag

```suggestion
  smul_mem' c x (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) := by simp [norm_smul, hx]
```

Cauchy-Schwarz helps
```suggestion
  rw [← norm_eq_zero]
  refine le_antisymm ?_ (by positivity)
  exact norm_inner_le_norm _ _ |>.trans <| by simp [h]
```

You don't want this to be explicit everywhere. Similarly, `𝕜` should only be explicit when the hypotheses don't mention `𝕜`, but the conclusion does (e.g., `inner_eq_zero_of_left`.
```suggestion
variable (E) in
```

I think this belongs closer to the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, as it's not specific to the `nullSubmodule`. Same for the `of_right` version. And `x` should be implicit because it's capable of being inferred from `h`.
```suggestion
lemma inner_eq_zero_of_left {x : E} (y : E) (h : ‖x‖ = 0) :
    ⟪x, y⟫_𝕜 = 0 := by
```

Name doesn't match, it should be `inner_eq_zero_of_right`. (or maybe both of these could just delete the word `of`)
```suggestion
lemma inner_eq_zero_of_right (x : E) {y : E} (h : ‖y‖ = 0) : ⟪x, y⟫_𝕜 = 0 := by
  rw [inner_eq_zero_symm, inner_eq_zero_of_left _ _ h]
```

```suggestion
lemma nullSubmodule_le_ker_toDualMap_right (x : E) : nullSubmodule 𝕜 E ≤ ker (toDualMap 𝕜 E x) :=
  fun _ ↦ inner_eq_zero_of_right 𝕜 x
```

```suggestion
/-- The kernel of the map `x ↦ ⟪·, x⟫` includes the null space. -/
lemma nullSubmodule_le_ker_toDualMap_left : nullSubmodule 𝕜 E ≤ ker (toDualMap 𝕜 E) :=
  fun _ hx ↦ ContinuousLinearMap.ext <| fun y ↦ inner_eq_zero_of_left 𝕜 y hx
```

optional, but I wanted you to know we had this lemma:
```suggestion
  · simpa [h] using norm_sub_norm_le x y
```
We should also have `norm_add_eq_norm`, and these can both go in an earlier file.
done and moved in `/Analysis/Normed/Group/Basic`
Why is this necessary now? If it isn't please remove it.

~~If I remove it, I get the error "ambiguous, possible interpretations" between `_root_` and `Filter`~~
sorry, it was another branch with new imports. here I can remove `_root_`.
ditto
same as above

```suggestion
lemma mem_nullSubgroup_iff {x : M} : x ∈ nullSubgroup ↔ ‖x‖ = 0 := Iff.rfl
```
Is there really no earlier place this can go? I would imagine it can live very near to `dist_eq_norm`.
I think this lemma is probably omitted deliberately; you're expected to perform the two rewrites separately, as mathlib has to draw the line against transitive rewrites somewhere.
removed the lemma

You want `M` to be explicit here.
```suggestion
variable (M) in
/-- The null subgroup with respect to the norm. -/
def nullSubgroup : AddSubgroup M where
```

Because you've defined this here, you're assuming that `E` is an inner product space and `𝕜` is `RCLike`, but there's no reason the definition needs to be anywhere near this restrictive. You're going to want to define `nullSubmodule` in a separate file, and then prove the results specific to inner product spaces here. In fact, I think it's only the `ker` results that stay in this file.
moved in `Analysis/Normed/Group/SeparationQuotient`
This lemma feels too contrived to me; the `norm_mk` that it uses is much stronger than the resulting lemma. I think it should be removed.
I agree with this. I think you should remove this lemma.
sorry, I had missed this. removed
Do you mean `NormedAddCommGroup (SeparationQuotient M)`? This is unclear.
yes, I expanded the docstring

untested
```suggestion
  neg_mem' {x} (hx : ‖x‖ = 0) := by simpa only [mem_setOf_eq, norm_neg] using hx
```

We already have this: [Zero.instNonempty](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Nonempty.html#Zero.instNonempty). You can check that it works by replacing this proof by `inferInstance` (and then deleting the result).
I see, removed
Please move this next to the definition of `nullSubmodule`.
done
@yoh-tanimoto I think you forgot to push this change.
Please mention `nullSubmodule` too in the module doc.
done. thanks for the review!
Can you add `left` and `right` versions here, as you did with `inner`?
for `norm_mul_eq_norm` I did it. what is the `left` version of `div`? or do you mean `‖x⁻¹ * y‖ = ‖y‖`?
I think your `div` version is fine. You can add the `inv` versions if you want; it's up to you.

```suggestion
lemma isClosed_nullSubgroup : IsClosed (nullSubgroup M : Set M) :=
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Dual, Analysis/Normed/Group/SeparationQuotient): add null subspaces

nodes.body:
### PR summary [a784e33936](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16707/commits/a784e339368d879d109e4803b415b1e4ae22c9d8)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Analysis/InnerProductSpace): weaken assumptions to `SeminormedAddCommGroup`

nodes.body:
I suspect that this is not the way to proceed here. Instead, I recommend using [SeparationQuotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Defs/Filter.html#SeparationQuotient).

If we don't already have it, you could show that if `X` is a `Seminormed*` then `SeparationQuotient X` is a `Normed*`. Then you could define the inner product space isntance on `SeparationQuotient X`.

The problem with putting this `InnerProductSpace` instance on `E / nullSpace \bbk E` is that we could end up with non-defeq instances later down the line. Moreover, `SeparationQuotient` does almost exactly what you want already, it just doesn't have the necessary instances yet.

@j-loreaux If I use `SeparationQuotient` and take the instance [SeparationQuotient.instAddCommGroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/SeparationQuotient.html#SeparationQuotient.instAddCommGroup), it is different from [AddSubgroup.seminormedAddCommGroupQuotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Quotient.html#AddSubgroup.seminormedAddCommGroupQuotient), correct? Do I have to define the norm again for `SeparationQuotient`?
Yes, it is certainly different, and you'll need to define the norm again, assuming the instance doesn't already exist. But I think this is the cleaner approach.
OK I will try. So I should prove all in [Quotient](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Quotient.html) again for `SeparationQuotient`, correct?
yes, I would.

You should be able to shortcut a little by: 
* Showing the `Inseparable` relation is an `AddCon`:
```lean
/-- `inseparableSetoid` is an additive congruence relation. -/
def inseparableAddCon [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] : AddCon E where
  __ := inseparableSetoid E
  add' {x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂} (hx : Inseparable _ _) (hy : Inseparable _ _) := show Inseparable _ _ by
    simp_rw [Metric.inseparable_iff_nndist, ← nonpos_iff_eq_zero] at hx hy ⊢
    exact (nndist_add_add_le _ _ _ _).trans <| add_nonpos hx hy
```
* Showing this congruence is the same as the one from your `nullSpace` submodule 
* Fiddling around with defeq to copy things over
Ok, I will try to simply following your comments.
I removed `.carrier` as suggested. In some places I had to use `have : x ∈ nullSpace ↔ x ∈ (@nullSpace M _ : Set M) := by rfl`. I wonder if there is a better way

> I removed `.carrier` as suggested. In some places I had to use `have : x ∈ nullSpace ↔ x ∈ (@nullSpace M _ : Set M) := by rfl`. I wonder if there is a better way

This theorem is called `SetLike.mem_coe`
thank you, I replaced all the immediate `have` with `SetLike.mem_coe`.
sorry, I wanted to change docstrings and theorem/instance names later. I know that the PR is still very much incomplete

I noticed that I need to define the lift of a linear map vanishing on the null space as a linear map. Where should I define it and how? In `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.SeparationQuotient` as a `CLM` or `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.SeparationQuotient`?

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Dual): weaken assumptions to SeminormedAddCommGroup

nodes.body:
Here's a much shorter way to get the `InnerProductSpace` instance on `SeparationQuotient`:
```lean
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Basic

variable {𝕜 E} [RCLike 𝕜] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] [InnerProductSpace 𝕜 E]

namespace SeparationQuotient

instance : Inner 𝕜 (SeparationQuotient E) where
  inner := SeparationQuotient.lift₂ Inner.inner fun _ _ _ _ hab hcd =>
    ((hab.prod hcd).map continuous_inner).eq

theorem inner_mk_mk (x y : E) :
  inner (mk x) (mk y) = (inner x y : 𝕜) := rfl

instance : InnerProductSpace 𝕜 (SeparationQuotient E) where
  norm_sq_eq_inner := Quotient.ind norm_sq_eq_inner
  conj_symm := Quotient.ind₂ inner_conj_symm
  add_left := Quotient.ind fun x => Quotient.ind₂ <| inner_add_left x
  smul_left := Quotient.ind₂ inner_smul_left

end SeparationQuotient
```
ah! what should I do with this PR then?

Probably the thing to do is go through the auxiliary lemmas you wrote and make PRs for the useful ones. Certainly we want the null space as a submodule, and the lift operations on separationQuotient look reasonable to have.
